bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Henry Rose Carter, Jr., October 25, 1888

div1.p: Carter describes his work and comments on the quarantine. He also provides family news.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Henry Rose Carter, Jr., October 25, 1888
div1.opener:
MARINE HOSPITAL SERVICE
1798 * U. S. * 1871
U. S. Marine-Hospital Service,
DISTRICT OF THE GULF,
Port of Ship Island, Miss, Surgeon's Office,
Oct 25, 1888.
My dear Ed:
div1.p:
I haven't answered y'r letter because
I have been too busy to do so. You see my evenings
are a dead loss. The musquitoes are so bad at night
that unless one gets under a bar, life is aburden, & even
on the nights when one might work, the habit of going to bed
early, formed during musquito nights, prevents.
Laura is getting well now, fairly well but will perforce
gain strength strongly. My diagnosis was I think correct,
just here at the end of the season too I have been over
run with vessels I have used 1255 lbs of sulphur sin
in the last 5 days: The worst of it is I do not exactly
know when the Q. will end. I hope on the 1st May; I
want to get ashore, save one day, May 2, I have not been
ashore since March, nor has any one of my employee's. The
can be no complaint of “communication with non-infected
districts from Quarantine” as far as Ship Island is
concerned. An “inspection service” will probably be kept
up (as in the port) all winter & vessels actually infected
(either at port of departure, in a transiter, will be placed in
Quarantine, This work is not strictly medical, at any rate
not therapeutic or pathological, but to me now it is very inter-
esting. I would be extremely glad to visit the different
Quarantines of the U. S.: I almost know, that the disinfection
(for vessels not infected), is extremely imperfect at most of
them, La Quarantine included, although the principle of its system is by far
the best. In these things it is the detail that counts & the detail is
left to employee's who have but little training & not too much
honesty. Now every process of every vessel (save 3) I have seen
the whole of myself going in hold, cabin, forecastle, wherever
the work was going on during the whole time of the disinfection.
I think I have two men so trained to my methods that
they can do very well with moderate supervision. I used
to see charts at the Hospital at N. G. of sailors who had come
through Quarantine with roaches & bed-bugs. Very few pass
through Ship Island, I don't feel as if the Jacksonville Quaran-
tine was very well managed, but I really don't know. The law un
der which Hamilton acted gives only power to enforce
the state law & Fla. state law was almost nil on health mat-
ters, & he really could not establish an efficient cordon, as he did at
Brownsville. Certainly a great many people left Jackson-
ville who should have passed through Q. The criminal
2
striving for theatrical effect of Atlanta & “opening their gates”
to the Jacksonville people was also a hard thing to fight. Un-
doubtedly the Decatur fever came from Atlanta.
The only perfect management of an epidemic I know, was that
of the Plague at Vittianka in/78 & is not possible in
America. I wish I had had Camp Perry in lieu of Guiteras
About my Fla. land, I have engaged to take it. At $3000, for
100 acres, & haven't seen it, I could get Fla. lands cheaper
now I think, & yet I still think it a good investment. No
interest is to be paid save on payments, due one year
from delivery of deed , I suppose about Nov 15 to 30.
I have paid $950 & have about $200 more ready. Can get
$730 from Oregon next April & will be able to pay
about $75.00 per month (except the two months when
I pay life insurance), except on months like last month
when I had of course extraordinary expenses. I can average
however $75, for 10 months so I can very nearly pay the
amount by the end of the year.

I had two Tampa Refugees here of whom I inquired a
bout the country, around Bloomingdale & they said that land around
Bloomingdale was little for sale & worth about $50
to $75 00/100. I will go there as soon as I can get away
from this place - i. e. when Quarantine is over. I
These blots are caused by slapping at musquitoes.
I have not been fishing since May or June, all of my spare
time being with L., but I may be able to go soon. The fishing here
is excellent, but unreliable, sometimes a great many & again
none. I have had some good sport with Alligators & Devil-
Fish. Catching the former with a noose & the latter with a harpoon
If you can find any thing about the latter you will find he is a very
tough customer. One towed me about 6 or 8 miles & then got off & I
caught a much smaller one which weighed 2400 lbs. The 1st
must have been 3000 or 3,500 & it was risky enough to be exciting.
I have done no medical reading since I've been here, partly
on account of my eyes; hurt by the glare, & partly because my
work required another class of thought & reading.

I am hoping to get into a decent house in a month or 6 weeks,
out at North Chandeleur & hope to have a disinfection station
fitted up so as really to do good sanitary work. I do believe
that there is no really good work of these kind done in Ameri-
ca in spite of the reports etc that the different state B's of Health
make. Mine is not good & yet I believe it to be all things considered
the best I know; almost infinite pains taking the place of
good apparatus. Do you know that we have more as many infected
ships here theseas La. has? owing of course to the class of ships that come
I have had 4 this year & La. so far only 2 & only 4 for last year. She
serves to Quarantine against Chagres Fever, why I don't know, we
have had nearly a hundred cases of that, I'm at the end of my paper,

I find this letter is almost entirely on sanitary matters, well I was
thinking of them. I have become a good boat sailor & Laura & Henry
go with me a good deal.

The former can help a good deal & both are intensely nauti-
cal & in no wise afraid of water, Laura, can steer, except “by the wind,” & both
of them row a little, but do not keep stroke well, are in good health
I wish I were going to meet you at home in November
If you think May would be improved by coming here, we will be glad to have her but
the social advantages are nil: warm sea air is
about the only attraction; only I hope to add oysters.
